image.altText: Photograph outside the Australian Tax Office headquarters

items.synopsis: Following an ABC Investigation, the Australian Tax Office admits criminals have fraudulently claimed more than $557 million from the Commonwealth using an identity loophole.

image.altText: Geoff and Rhonda doing a puzzle.

items.synopsis: Geoff is selectively mute and has a fragile X syndrome. When his mother engaged a disability service to take him to work, she didn't know it would use up almost all his NDIS funding.

title.children: Geoff was driven to work three days a week. He received a $700 invoice for it

items.synopsis: The effect of head knocks over Gordi Kirkbank-Ellis's decades-long sporting career isn’t immediately obvious. That is, until you see what’s happening to his brain.

title.children: The effect of decades of head knocks isn't immediately obvious on Gordi. That is, until you see his brain

image.altText: Portrait of Veronica Corstorphine, who was allegedly murdered in Launceston

items.synopsis: A Tasmanian court dismisses an appeal by a woman who suffocated her mother with a pillow in 2019 — with one judge dissenting, saying the evidence from one expert "fatally infected" the fairness of the trial.

title.children: Woman who suffocated mother with pillow in 2019 loses appeal

image.altText: A red up arrow next to a percentage sign on top of an aerial view of dozens of houses.

items.synopsis: The level of mortgage arrears is creeping higher and the number of borrowers at risk of mortgage stress is at its highest level since 2008.

title.children: Mortgage arrears rising as 'at risk' borrowers hit pre-GFC peaks

image.altText: young woman tossing a fleece on the table for classing

items.synopsis: Seven out of 10 wool classing trainees in Australia are now women — and 21-year-old Cally Spangler is one of them. It's a trend the industry is embracing, as it looks to renew its ageing workforce.

title.children: When Cally gave working a woolshed a try, she 'just loved it'. Here's why

image.altText: A family sits around and reads a book.

items.synopsis: This Dolly Parton program sends children a free book every month until they turn five. Results show these kids are being read to far more often than the average Australian child.

title.children: This city signed up newborns to a reading program created by Dolly Parton. These are the results

image.altText: Three women and four men standing on the steps of Government House

items.synopsis: After at least five cabinet reshuffles in the past few years, Tasmania's new Liberal ministry has been sworn in. It's unlikely to herald any monumental policy changes.

title.children: New Tasmanian cabinet unlikely to chart new course

image.altText: A graphic showing a confused person looking at different plastics.

items.synopsis: Do you know your PP from your HDPE, and your PVC from your soft plastics? Plastic recycling is a minefield, so here's how to tell what you're dealing with and which bin you should put it in.

title.children: Plastic not so fantastic: Do you know which numbers can't be recycled?

image.altText: A woman with glasses wearing a high-vis vest stands in front of plastic waste piles.

items.synopsis: Liz Kasell, who founded the REDcycle soft plastic recycling scheme which collapsed with thousands of tonnes of plastic stockpiled in warehouses across the country, insists she believed materials being collected by the company would be saved from landfill.

title.children: REDcycle founder says she had 'no doubt' stockpiled plastic would be recycled

image.altText: A woman with dark hair pulled into a bun smiles, standing in front of a floor to ceiling book shelf.

items.synopsis: Kamilaroi woman Louise Taylor will be appointed the first Indigenous female Supreme Court judge today. It is the second time she has made history, after she was appointed as the ACT's first Indigenous magistrate in 2018.

title.children: Louise Taylor will become Australia's first female Indigenous Supreme Court judge. It's not the first time she's made history

image.altText: A grand, multi-story English country home, made from stone, with pillars and grand windows, including a garden with hedges

items.synopsis: Britain is having a belated reckoning with its slave past — a past that is closely connected to rum.

title.children: 'A wicked, evil mindset': Behind many historic British buildings, there's a very uncomfortable truth

image.altText: A centrelink sign with on a building with a reflection

items.synopsis: Behavioural economics is a discipline that seems blind to empathy. The care with which Robodebt letters were designed — and the so-called science behind those devastating design decisions — showed what it could do, writes Peter Martin.

title.children: Great care was taken over the design of Robodebt letters, right down to the colour. Here's why

image.altText: A woman in a two-tone denim jacket, stands at her kitchen bench.

items.synopsis: One in 25 Australians have lodged an insurance claim because of extreme weather since 2020, but should the remaining policyholders be responsible for sharing the cost of increased premiums?

title.children: Rachel's home insurance payments increased by $840 this year. She's just one Australian sharing the cost of more claims

image.altText: fresh fruit in aisles of a grocery shop

items.synopsis: Economists predict rapid rate rises by the Reserve Bank will see a slow down in price rises over the June quarter, while the International Monetary Fund warns of persistent challenges for the global economy. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Inflation pull-back predicted, IMF warns of economic challenges, US stocks rise

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The International Monetary Fund expects global economic growth to slow from 3.5 per cent last year to 3 per cent this year and next amid high inflation, the war in Ukraine, and a slowing China. The IMF slightly upgraded its global growth forecasts in its latest World Economic Outlook, but chief economist Pierre-Olivier Gourinchas says “yet many challenges still cloud the horizon, and it is too early to celebrate." Mr Gourinchas says the global economy continues to gradually recover from the pandemic and the signs of progress are undeniable. However, he says interest rate rises by central banks are slowing economies and core inflation remains well above central bank targets. The IMF's World Economic Outlook predicts that global inflation is expected to fall from 8.7 per cent in 2022 to 6.8 per cent in 2023 and 5.2 per cent in 2024. But it said the threat of higher inflation due to Russia's invasion of Ukraine and extreme weather could lead central banks to hike interest rates or cause world leaders to enact more restrictive economic policies. And the IMF warned that China's slow recovery following the reopening of its economy after the pandemic “shows signs of losing steam", and a deeper contraction in the real estate sector remained a risk. It left its forecasts for Chinese growth at 5.2 per cent this year and 4.5 per cent in 2024. with AP/Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: IMF says global economy on track but not out of the woods yet

children.content: The International Monetary Fund expects global economic growth to slow from 3.5 per cent last year to 3 per cent this year and next amid high inflation, the war in Ukraine, and a slowing China.

The IMF slightly upgraded its global growth forecasts in its latest World Economic Outlook, but chief economist Pierre-Olivier Gourinchas says “yet many challenges still cloud the horizon, and it is too early to celebrate."
Mr Gourinchas says the global economy continues to gradually recover from the pandemic and the signs of progress are undeniable.
However, he says interest rate rises by central banks are slowing economies and core inflation remains well above central bank targets.

props.alt: Table showing IMF forecasts for the world economy

children.content: Global growth
(IMF)
The IMF's World Economic Outlook predicts that global inflation is expected to fall from 8.7 per cent in 2022 to 6.8 per cent in 2023 and 5.2 per cent in 2024.

But it said the threat of higher inflation due to Russia's invasion of Ukraine and extreme weather could lead central banks to hike interest rates or cause world leaders to enact more restrictive economic policies.

And the IMF warned that China's slow recovery following the reopening of its economy after the pandemic “shows signs of losing steam", and a deeper contraction in the real estate sector remained a risk.
It left its forecasts for Chinese growth at 5.2 per cent this year and 4.5 per cent in 2024.
with AP/Reuters

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Commonwealth Bank's Stephen Wu expects inflation over the June quarter to be driven by household goods, rent, food, and takeaway, as well as the cost of insurance. "Insurance and financial services will be an outsized contributor to inflation, with insurance premiums up by 5.3 per cent in quarter 2, 2023 (June quarter), and more than 14 per cent from a year ago." "Premiums are rising in part due to the occurrence of natural disasters, and pandemic related supply chain issues." However, he notes that rate hikes are working to slow the economy and contain inflationary pressures. Westpac's Justin Smirk is predicting an easing in housing costs because of state government rebates driving down electricity prices over the June quarter, which he expects to offset higher rents. Education and medical costs will also fall after scheduled price increases over the March quarter. "Overall, the June quarter CPI is set to confirm that inflationary pressures peaked in late 2022 and continues to moderate as we move through 2023." "However, it will also continue to highlight that core inflation remains significantly above the top of the RBA's target band and is not likely to return to being within the band anytime soon."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Big bank economists on inflation

children.content: The Commonwealth Bank's Stephen Wu expects inflation over the June quarter to be driven by household goods, rent, food, and takeaway, as well as the cost of insurance.

"Insurance and financial services will be an outsized contributor to inflation, with insurance premiums up by 5.3 per cent in quarter 2, 2023 (June quarter), and more than 14 per cent from a year ago."
"Premiums are rising in part due to the occurrence of natural disasters, and pandemic related supply chain issues."
However, he notes that rate hikes are working to slow the economy and contain inflationary pressures.
Westpac's Justin Smirk is predicting an easing in housing costs because of state government rebates driving down electricity prices over the June quarter, which he expects to offset higher rents.
Education and medical costs will also fall after scheduled price increases over the March quarter.
"Overall, the June quarter CPI is set to confirm that inflationary pressures peaked in late 2022 and continues to moderate as we move through 2023."
"However, it will also continue to highlight that core inflation remains significantly above the top of the RBA's target band and is not likely to return to being within the band anytime soon."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The big four banks are predicting the pace of price rises will slow over the June quarter, but they still expect annual price increases of at least 6 per cent. We did see price increases ease over the year to May to 5.6 per cent because of cheaper petrol, and inflation actually fell over the month, which indicates rate rises are slowing the economy. But the price of essential items like food and rent remain stubbornly high. Headline inflation forecasts: CBA: 0.9 per cent June quarter, 6.1 per cent annual ANZ: 1 per cent June quarter, 6.2 per cent annual NAB: 0.9 per cent June quarter, 6.1 per cent annual Westpac: 1.1% June quarter, 6.3 per cent annual RBA: 1.1 June quarter, 6.3 per cent annual The Commonwealth Bank is predicting a final 0.25 per cent rate rise next week by the RBA, ANZ expects the central bank to stay on hold, and Westpac and National Australia Bank are predicting two more rate rises this year.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What are the big banks predicting on inflation?

children.content: The big four banks are predicting the pace of price rises will slow over the June quarter, but they still expect annual price increases of at least 6 per cent.
We did see price increases ease over the year to May to 5.6 per cent because of cheaper petrol, and inflation actually fell over the month, which indicates rate rises are slowing the economy.
But the price of essential items like food and rent remain stubbornly high.

props.alt: graph showing inflation from May 2019 to 2023

children.content: Inflation
(ABS)
Headline inflation forecasts:
CBA: 0.9 per cent June quarter, 6.1 per cent annual
ANZ: 1 per cent June quarter, 6.2 per cent annual
NAB: 0.9 per cent June quarter, 6.1 per cent annual
Westpac: 1.1% June quarter, 6.3 per cent annual
RBA: 1.1 June quarter, 6.3 per cent annual

The Commonwealth Bank is predicting a final 0.25 per cent rate rise next week by the RBA, ANZ expects the central bank to stay on hold, and Westpac and National Australia Bank are predicting two more rate rises this year.

image.altText: A man in a tuxedo and a woman in a formal black gown

image.altText: Greyhound legs and lower torso while the animal is running.
